questions.text: Identify the amputation shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shows bones- tibia and fibula. BKA is an amputation that occurs below the knee joint, which is characterized by the preservation of the knee but the removal of the lower leg including the tibia and fibula. This type of amputation leaves the knee joint intact and results in a residual limb that ends just below the knee.

Lower Limb Amputation and its types:

Type of Amputation

Description

Indications

Functionality and Prosthesis Considerations

Partial Foot Amputation

Involves the removal of part of the foot, including toes or part of the forefoot.
  • Severe trauma
  • Diabetes-related complications (e.g., gangrene)
  • Infection
  • Retains some function of the foot for walking
  • Custom prostheses for toes and forefoot

Transmetatarsal Amputation (TMA)

Amputation through the metatarsal bones, removing the forefoot but leaving the midfoot and hindfoot intact.
  • Severe foot injury
  • Diabetes-related complications
  • Gangrene or infection
  • Often requires a prosthesis that fits the residual part of the foot for better weight-bearing

Lisfranc Amputation

Removal of the forefoot, including the toes and metatarsal bones, but preserving the hindfoot and ankle.
  • Severe trauma
  • Chronic infection
  • Vascular disease
  • Prosthetic options are complex due to the loss of the midfoot
  • Often uses a custom device

Syme’s Amputation (Option D)

Removal of the foot at the ankle joint, with the heel pad being preserved.
  • Trauma
  • Severe infections
  • Vascular disease (e.g., gangrene)
  • Functional prosthesis can be used, providing near-normal walking function
  • Heel pad aids in load-bearing

Transtibial Amputation (Below-Knee)

Amputation below the knee joint, typically through the tibia and fibula.
  • Severe trauma
  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Diabetes complications
  • Tumors
  • Functional prostheses (below-knee prosthesis) with ankle and foot components
  • Retains knee function

Knee Disarticulation

Amputation through the knee joint, preserving the femur while removing the tibia and fibula.
  • Severe trauma
  • Infection
  • Vascular disease
  • Bone cancer
  • Prosthetic knee and foot required
  • Retains better residual limb length for prosthesis fitting

Transfemoral Amputation (Above-Knee) (Option A)

Amputation above the knee joint, through the femur.
  • Severe trauma
  • Cancer
  • Chronic infection
  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Requires a prosthesis with both knee and ankle components
  • More energy is required for walking

Hip Disarticulation

Removal of the entire leg at the hip joint, including the femur.
  • Severe trauma
  • Tumors
  • Vascular disease
  • Severe infection
  • Prosthetic limb involves the hip joint, requires specialized sockets and joints for movement

Above elbow amputation (Option C) involves the removal of the arm above the elbow joint. The amputation is performed through the humerus, leaving the upper arm but removing the forearm and hand.

questions.text: A motorcyclist met with a road traffic accident and had a metacarpal fracture. Hypothenar atrophy is observed. Identify the nerve involved.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Ulnar nerve

Explanation:

  • The ulnar nerve supplies the hypothenar muscles. Any damage to the ulnar nerve in case of a metacarpal fracture can lead to hypothenar atrophy.

 

Ulnar nerve supply in the hand:

The ulnar nerve travels alongside the ulnar artery and gives off a palmar cutaneous branch before reaching the flexor retinaculum, supplying the ulnar side of the palm & enters Guyon’s canal & divides into:

  • Superficial Branch: Supplies the skin of the medial 1½ fingers & Palmaris brevis.
  • Deep Branch: Supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand except muscles of thenar eminence & 1st two lumbricals and terminates supplying Adductor pollicis, aka Graveyard of Ulnar nerve.

Guyon’s Canal (Ulnar Tunnel Syndrome):

  • Compression of the ulnar nerve within Guyon’s canal at the wrist.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Claw-Hand Deformity: The ring and little fingers exhibit pronounced ulnar claw hand when compared to injury of the ulnar nerve at the elbow (ulnar paradox) due to preserved function of the FDP, resulting in marked flexion of DIP joints.
    • Atrophy of the Hypothenar Eminence (Option B)
    • Loss of Finger Abduction and Adduction
    • Positive Froment’s Sign: Unable to hold the book between thumb and index indicates weakness in the adductor pollicis. DIP Of thumb compensates for adductor pollicis weakness and thumb flexion occurs.

 

Radial nerve (Options A) Damage to the radial nerve leads to wrist drop (inability to extend the wrist) and loss of elbow extension.

Musculocutaneous nerve (Options C) injury causes weakness in elbow flexion, forearm supination and shoulder flexion. Sensory loss on the lateral aspect of the forearm is also seen

Median nerve (Options D) lesion causes difficulty flexing the index and middle fingers and loss of thumb opposition, but it does not affect hypothenar eminence.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with limping gait and left hip pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Avascular necrosis

 

Explanation:

This patient likely has avascular necrosis (AVN), a condition where bone cells die due to a lack of blood supply.

  • It often affects weight-bearing joints like the hip, knee, talus, and humeral head, with the hip being most common.
  • The X-ray shows flattening of the top and side of the femoral head, a typical sign. However, MRI is the best for diagnosing and staging AVN.
  • Initial investigation for avascular necrosis (AVN) is typically an X-ray, but it may not show signs until at least 3 months after onset.
  • X-ray findings include increased bone density and a crescent sign, indicating a tangential fracture line below the joint surface.
  • Radio scintigraphy with mTc-sulphur colloid or CT scan can be used.
  • MRI is the preferred choice due to its ability to detect early marrow changes and bone ischemia.
  • Intramedullary pressure measurement and biopsy are other options for diagnosis.
  • Biopsy, though invasive, offers early detection and intervention possibilities with medical treatment.

 

Tuberculosis of the hip (Option A): Irregular and hazy joint margins, destruction of bone on either side of the joint, erosions, and reduced joint space are classical plain X-ray findings.

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B): It primarily affects small joints of the hands. Hallmark radiographic findings include marginal erosions, soft tissue swelling, osteoporosis, and joint space narrowing.


Ankylosing spondylitis (Option C): Spine and sacroiliac joints are involved. Plain X-ray of the spine shows erosions at the corners of vertebral bodies with reactive sclerosis, vertebral body squaring, and a characteristic bamboo spine appearance.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent observations manifest itself later in compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Paralysis

Explanation:

  • Paralysis is a late finding in compartment syndrome, indicating severe and advanced muscle and nerve damage. It is crucial to recognize and treat compartment syndrome promptly to prevent irreversible tissue damage and complications.

 

Compartment syndrome:

  • Compartment syndrome is a condition where increased pressure within a closed muscle compartment compromises the circulation and function of the tissues within that space. The classic symptoms and signs include the "5 Ps": pain, pallor, paresthesia (tingling or numbness), paralysis, and pulselessness.

Clinical Features:

Initial Symptoms of Compartment Syndrome (in chronological order)

  • Pain (Option D): The earliest symptom, worsened by passive extension of fingers - Stretch pain
  • Pallor (Option A): Skin may appear pale due to reduced blood supply.
  • Pulselessness (Option C): Diminished or absent radial pulse.
  • Paresthesia: Numbness or tingling due to nerve compression.
  • Paralysis: Weakness or inability to move fingers, indicating nerve ischemia.

 

Causes include:

  1. Tight bandages and dressings
  2. Animal bites
  3. Burns
  4. Intensive and excessive exercises
  5. Muscle hypertrophy
  6. Neoplasms
  7. Bleeding into a closed compartment (injury to a vessel, congenital or acquired disorder)
  8. Injections in the forearm
  9. Surgery on the forearm

 

Common sites:

  • Most common: Flexor compartment of the forearm.
  • 2nd Most common: Anterior and deep posterior compartments of the legs.
  • Rare sites: Buttocks, shoulder, hand, foot, arm, and lumbar paraspinal muscles.

questions.text: As the intern on duty, your responsibility includes attending to patients involved in a road traffic accident. Identify the patient from the options below for whom you would promptly contact the orthopaedic resident on call.

choices.text: Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds in his fingers
Patient with a fractured arm with a 10 cm long incision over the arm
Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of 5 seconds in his fingers

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of 5 seconds in his fingers

Explanation:

  • Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of 5 seconds in his fingers is a critical choice because a capillary refill time of 5 seconds indicates potential circulatory compromise, which is a medical emergency. Such a delay in capillary refill suggests that the blood flow to the fingers is inadequate, possibly due to vascular injury or severe swelling, necessitating immediate orthopaedic evaluation and intervention to prevent further complications, such as limb ischemia

Orthopedic Emergencies:

  • Open fractures and dislocations
  • Hip dislocations (risk of AVN)
  • Neural compromise, especially with spinal injury
  • Symptoms or signs of neurovascular injury (numbness, paresis, poor perfusion)
  • Acute septic arthritis and osteomyelitis
  • Compartment syndrome (eg, pain out of proportion to injuries, pallor, paresthesias, coolness, pulselessness)
  • Vascular injuries (e.g., knee dislocation)
  • Exsanguinating pelvic fractures

Incorrect Options:

The patient with recurrent shoulder dislocation (Option A) may require follow-up but does not represent an acute emergency.

The patient with a fractured arm and capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds (Option B) indicates adequate perfusion and does not require immediate intervention.

The patient with a fractured arm and a 10 cm long incision (Option C) may need attention but does not exhibit signs of circulatory compromise as severe as the fourth option.

questions.text: A 79 yrs old lady had a fall in the bathroom, the following X-rays were taken in order to make a diagnosis. Which of the following is treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hemiarthroplasty

Explanation:

  • Hemiarthroplasty is the preferred treatment for displaced femoral neck fractures in elderly patients, particularly those who are inactive or have multiple comorbidities. It involves replacing the femoral head while leaving the acetabulum intact.

In a femoral neck fracture, especially in elderly patients, the classic presentation of the limb includes external rotation and shortening.

  • The external rotation occurs due to the pull of the external rotator muscles, such as the gluteus maximus and the short external rotators, on the distal femoral fragment.
  • Shortening of the limb occurs due to muscle contraction and overriding of the bone fragments, particularly in displaced fractures.

Fracture of the Neck of Femur

  • The fracture of the neck of the femur is a significant injury, particularly in the elderly, and is often associated with osteoporosis and trauma.

Etiology

Low-Energy Trauma

Common in elderly with osteoporosis; simple fall from standing height can cause a fracture.

Osteoporosis

Age-related bone loss; post-menopausal women at higher risk; fractures occur with minimal trauma.

Pathological Fractures

Caused by conditions like metastatic bone disease, multiple myeloma, or Paget’s disease; minimal force needed for fracture.

Stress Fractures

Seen in athletes or military personnel due to repetitive stress.

Clinical Presentation

Pain

Groin pain radiating to medial thigh or knee; sharp pain worsened by movement.

Inability to Bear Weight

Unable to stand or walk due to pain, less severe in stress fractures.

Attitude of affected limb

Shortened and externally rotated limb in displaced fractures; limited internal rotation and flexion.

Bruising and Swelling

Minimal swelling due to deep femoral neck location; sometimes bruising around hip or groin.

Diagnosis

Imaging

X-ray (AP and lateral views) is the primary modality; fractures are classified using the Garden classification.

 

Treatment Options
  • Non-displaced: Internal fixation (e.g., cannulated screws)
  • Displaced: Surgical fixation (hemiarthroplasty, total hip replacement)

Complications

High risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis

 

 

Garden’s classification

Treatment in adults

Treatment in children

Garden’s type 1

(incomplete, impacted, or abducted fracture)
  • Conservative methods
  • Immobilization in a Thomas splint with traction
  • Internal fixation with screws (if displacement is feared)
  • Hip spica (Option B ruled out)
  • Traction is applied through a pin (Moore’s pin) or wire in older adolescents

Garden’s type 2

(complete but undisplaced)

Internal fixation with cannulated screws, dynamic hip screws, proximal femoral locking plates, and cephalomedullary nails.

Garden’s type 3

(complete & partially displaced)

  • Hemiarthroplasty (done in inactive elderly of >60years of age with comorbidities)
  • Total hip arthroplasty (done in active older patients)
  • Internal fixation (done in young adults)

Internal fixation (using Knowle’s screw)

Garden’s type 4

(complete & fully displaced)

 

Total Hip Replacement (Option C) is considered in active older adults with femoral neck fractures, especially when there's a need to address both the femoral head and acetabulum. However, it is usually reserved for patients who are more active and have fewer comorbidities than those typically treated with hemiarthroplasty.

Nailing (Option D) (intramedullary fixation) is generally used for fractures of the femoral shaft or intertrochanteric fractures but is not typically indicated for displaced femoral neck fractures, especially in elderly patients. It is more suitable for younger patients with better bone quality and fewer comorbid conditions.

questions.text: As the intern on duty, your responsibility includes attending to patients involved in a road traffic accident. Identify the patient from the options below for whom you would promptly contact the orthopaedic resident on call.

choices.text: Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds in his fingers
Patient with a fractured arm with intact skin and minimal swelling.
Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of 5 seconds in his fingers

questions.solution:
• Capillary refill time (CRT) > 2 seconds indicates delayed perfusion and possible vascular injury or compartment syndrome.

  • CRT of 5 seconds is a red flag suggesting limb ischemia, which requires urgent orthopaedic and possibly vascular intervention.

Orthopedic Emergency Assessment in Trauma

Parameter Critical Concern
Capillary refill time > 2 seconds = vascular compromise
Limb color and temperature Pallor/coldness = poor perfusion
Pulse examination Absent/diminished distal pulses = arterial injury
Skin status Open wounds = open fracture → risk of infection
Pain disproportionate to injury Suspect compartment syndrome
Neurological status Paresthesia, motor weakness = possible nerve injury
Swelling or tense compartments Consider fasciotomy if compartment pressure is high

 

Orthopedic Emergencies in Trauma

Category Examples Urgency
Open fractures Bone exposed or wound >1 cm over fracture site Emergency ortho consult
Vascular compromise Absent pulses, CRT >2 sec, cold limb Emergency ortho + vascular
Compartment syndrome Pain out of proportion, paresthesia, pallor, pulselessness, paralysis Fasciotomy indicated
Joint dislocations Shoulder, knee, hip dislocations Urgent (but not always emergency)
Spinal trauma Neurological deficits, high-impact injury Immobilize + MRI/CT
Pelvic fractures Risk of hemorrhagic shock Emergency trauma care

Recurrent shoulder dislocation (Option A):
Chronic issue; not a priority unless there are neurovascular signs.

Capillary refill < 3 seconds (Option B):
Indicates adequate distal perfusion. No urgent ortho consult needed.

Fractured arm with intact skin and minimal swelling (Option C):
Stable closed fracture without signs of vascular compromise; managed routinely.

questions.text: For hypertrophic non-union following a fracture, the most appropriate treatment
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Stabilization

  • Hypertrophic non-union refers to a type of non-healing fracture where there is excessive callus formation at the fracture site, but the bone ends fail to unite. In this case, the most appropriate treatment is stabilization, which involves providing mechanical support and immobilization to the fractured bone. Stabilization can be achieved using various methods such as external fixation, internal fixation with plates and screws, or intramedullary nails. Stabilization promotes bone healing by reducing motion at the fracture site, allowing for the formation of a more stable environment that encourages bone union.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Bone grafting- While bone grafting can be a useful treatment option for certain types of non-union, it is not the first-line treatment for hypertrophic non-union. Hypertrophic non-union typically involves adequate callus formation, indicating that there is potential for bone healing. Therefore, stabilization alone is often sufficient to promote bone union in hypertrophic non-union cases, without the need for additional bone grafting.

Option C: Stabilization and bone grafting- In hypertrophic non-union, where there is excessive callus formation, stabilization alone is usually effective in promoting bone healing. The addition of bone grafting may not be necessary in this situation, as the existing callus provides a favorable environment for bone union. Therefore, stabilization and bone grafting are not typically combined as the primary treatment for hypertrophic non-union.

Option D: None of the above- The correct answer is not "None of the above" because stabilization is indeed an appropriate treatment option for hypertrophic non-union. While bone grafting may be indicated in certain types of non-union, it is not the most appropriate treatment for hypertrophic non-union.

questions.text: What is the earliest indication of acute compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • The earliest symptom of acute compartment syndrome is pain.
  • Acute compartment syndrome is a serious condition that occurs when pressure within a muscle compartment increases to a level that restricts blood flow and causes tissue damage. It most commonly affects the limbs, especially the lower leg.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Pallor: Pallor, or paleness of the skin, can occur in advanced stages of compartment syndrome when the blood flow to the affected muscles and tissues is severely compromised. However, pallor is not an early symptom and may not be present in the initial stages.

Option C. Paresthesia: Paresthesia refers to abnormal sensations, such as tingling or numbness. It can occur as the condition progresses and nerve function becomes compromised. Similar to pallor, paresthesia is not an early symptom and may develop in later stages.

Option D. Paralysis: Paralysis, or loss of muscle function, is a late sign of compartment syndrome and is typically indicative of severe tissue damage and nerve involvement. It is not an early symptom.

Correct marking is Option C

  • Sequestrum:
    • In the context of orthopedics, a sequestrum refers to a fragment of dead or necrotic bone that has become separated from the surrounding healthy bone. It typically occurs as a result of chronic osteomyelitis, which is a bone infection. The sequestrum is a non-viable piece of bone that lacks a blood supply and is often surrounded by a layer of inflammatory tissue called the involucrum. Treatment for a sequestrum usually involves surgical removal to promote healing and prevent the spread of infection.
  • Involucrum:
    • Involucrum is a term used to describe a layer of new bone that forms around a sequestrum or a chronic bone infection. It is part of the body's defense mechanism to isolate and contain the infection. The involucrum serves as a protective barrier, surrounding the sequestrum and helping to limit the spread of infection to healthy bone. It is composed of new bone formation and is often seen in cases of chronic osteomyelitis. Surgical intervention may be required to address the underlying infection and promote healing.
  • Cloaca
    • In anatomy, a cloaca is a structure found in certain animals where the urinary, reproductive, and gastrointestinal tracts open into a common chamber or cavity

questions.text: An elderly woman involved in a road traffic accident presents with difficulty in breathing and altered mental status. D-Dimer is elevated. X-ray findings are suggestive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Fat embolism

Explanation:

The patient's presentation following a road traffic accident is highly suggestive of a fat embolism syndrome. This condition occurs when fat globules from the bone marrow are released into the bloodstream after a long bone fracture, traveling to the lungs and brain. The classic triad of symptoms includes:

  • Respiratory Distress: This is the most common symptom, typically occurring 24-72 hours after the trauma. The fat emboli obstruct the pulmonary capillaries, leading to hypoxia and respiratory failure. The chest X-ray often shows bilateral patchy infiltrates, mimicking acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), as seen in the image provided.
  • Neurologic Changes: These can range from altered mental status to confusion, agitation, and even coma, as the fat emboli affect the cerebral circulation.
  • Petechial Rash: A characteristic, but not always present, rash of tiny red spots on the chest, neck, and axilla is a classic finding.

An elevated D-dimer is a non-specific finding that can be seen in both fat embolism and pulmonary embolism, as it indicates a breakdown of a clot. However, the combination of respiratory distress and neurological changes following a long bone fracture (common in road traffic accidents) makes a fat embolism the most likely diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Gas gangrene (Option A) is a severe bacterial infection that would present with crepitus (a crackling sensation under the skin) and a foul-smelling discharge, not the respiratory and neurological symptoms described.

Infection (Option C) would typically present with fever and leukocytosis, which are not the primary features of this acute post-traumatic event.

Pulmonary embolism (Option D) is a similar condition but lacks the characteristic petechial rash and is less likely to cause the specific neurological changes associated with fat embolism. While a D-dimer would be elevated, the clinical picture points more strongly to fat embolism.
